item.title: Jobs with cats: from vets to kitten socialisers and more - The Telegraph
item.description:
Jobs with cats: from vets to kitten socialisers and more  The Telegraph

The National Cat Adoption Centre is a remarkable place for many reasons: not least, that it’s the biggest centre for rescued cats in the United Kingdom. The centre has many employees, working with cats in different ways. Three of the more intriguing “cat jobs” are a dedicated in-house vet, volunteer kitten socialisers and volunteer cat desensitisers. To find out what these roles involve, read on. In-house veterinary surgeon A vet working in a cat adoption centre may seem like an obvious niche, but in fact one of the unusual aspects of the centre is that it has its own dedicated in-house vet...

item.title: Claws come out on Twitter after footage of woman striking & robbing stray cat goes viral (VIDEO) - RT
item.description:
Claws come out on Twitter after footage of woman striking & robbing stray cat goes viral (VIDEO)  RT

A Turkish woman has come under fire after footage of her stealing a blanket from a stray cat before striking the animal with it went viral. People took to Twitter to brand her a “brutal thief.” The footage shows the white cat hanging around on the side of a street next to a cardboard box, supposedly the feline’s home, where the stray animal used to sleep and keep warm in chilling temperatures. The box contained a tiny coloured blanket. A woman in a grey coat passes the cat and affectionately pats him on the head before moving on. Another woman, in a black hooded coat and with bare legs, the...

item.title: How pets improve mental health issues, from depression to PTSD - The Independent
item.description:
How pets improve mental health issues, from depression to PTSD  The Independent

The comforting padding of feet across the otherwise silent house, the welcoming nudge of wet nose on arm and the soothing sense of unconditional love can make lives tainted by mental health more bearable. Formerly love-deprived Nell, my rescue spaniel, loves her cuddles, and she “asks” for them on a daily basis. The strength of her unconditional and innocent sense of love is palpable and we both derive comfort and a sense of calm from that closeness. Just by stroking, sitting next to or playing with a pet can help to relax and calm someone with a mental health condition. Dogs especially wil...

item.title: The stunning national park where the painted wolves of Dynasties roam - The Telegraph
item.description:
The stunning national park where the painted wolves of Dynasties roam  The Telegraph

A trio of celebrated species - lions, emperor penguins and chimpanzees - starred in the first three episodes of David Attenborough’s Dynasties. Last night’s show, however, focused on a little-known creature: the African wild dog, or painted wolf. Unfamiliar they may be, but the plight of these animals was still utterly gripping, a family feud akin to Game of Thrones in which two packs - one led by alpha-female Tate, the other by her daughter, Blacktip - fought over territory while dodging lions, crocodiles and hyenas. “Two years in the making, this was a superb piece of filmmaking, offering...

item.title: Adopting a pet can help relieve symptoms of depression, study claims - The Independent
item.description:
Adopting a pet can help relieve symptoms of depression, study claims  The Independent

The old adage that "dogs are a man’s best friend" might sound hackneyed and a little sexist, but new research reveals there is some truth in it, at least where someone’s mental health is concerned. According to a study published in a Journal of Psychiatric Research, adopting a pet could offer respite to those with severe depression that has low rates of remission and cannot be easily treated with antidepressant medications or psychotherapy. Two Portuguese researchers recruited 80 participants with this kind of depression, known as "treatment-resistant major depressive disorder”, and found t...

item.title: Householder in court for catching neighbour's cat in fox snare after it repeatedly fouled his hot tub - The Telegraph
item.description:
Householder in court for catching neighbour's cat in fox snare after it repeatedly fouled his hot tub  The Telegraph

A householder who tried everything he could think of to stop his neighbour’s cat fouling his jacuzzi, before trapping it in a fox snare, has been warned he could go to jail if he targets the pet again. Laurence Brown, 60, tried putting up screens and putting down pepper and lion dung after the cat repeatedly defecated in the outdoor hut tub. But a court was told that his efforts to keep the cat out “appeared only to make his neighbour’s pet more determined”. He eventually bought a fox snare online and set it at a spot where the cat was squeezing through the palings of the fence that divided...

item.title: Melanie Breese stopped to pat a stray cat and the resulting attack left her in hospital for three days - ABC News
item.description:
Melanie Breese stopped to pat a stray cat and the resulting attack left her in hospital for three days  ABC News

By Charlotte Hamlyn A Perth woman has spent three days in hospital after being attacked by a stray cat while walking near her home, prompting a warning about the very high risk of infection posed by the animals. Melanie Breese suffered scratches and puncture wounds to her hand and wrist after leaning down to pat the cat. "It looked a lot like my own cat and I just decided I'd like to give it a little pat on the head," Mrs Breese said. "It gave me no warning, no hissing or any indication of what it was going to do. "But the next thing I knew I was recoiling back, and the cat's claws were sti...

item.title: Pet Subjects: Telegraph vet Pete Wedderburn answers your questions - The Telegraph
item.description:
Pet Subjects: Telegraph vet Pete Wedderburn answers your questions  The Telegraph

Dear Pete Since Purdey, our much-loved 12-year-old German pointer, died, we've been thinking about getting another dog. However, our two 14-year-old cats seem much more relaxed and confident in Purdey's absence. We don't want to upset their newfound tranquillity. What do you think? VA, Somerset Dear VA Cats can live into their 20s these days, so you could be dogless for many years to come. The alternative is to choose a dog with a history of being cat-friendly, and create spaces where your cats can relax without fear of a dog annoying them (try installing a cat tree from cattree.uk). Credit...

item.title: Pet owners who feed their cats a vegan diet could face prosecution - The Telegraph
item.description:
Pet owners who feed their cats a vegan diet could face prosecution  The Telegraph

The RSPCA has warned cat owners they could be prosecuted for feeding their pets vegan food. One in six pet food suppliers has branched out into supplying vegan or vegetarian food for animals as owners embraced the new trend over ethical concerns with meat diets. But yesterday the animal rescue charity said those with cats could end up making their pet "seriously ill" by placing them on exclusively plant-based diets - and potentially risk them getting a criminal record. A spokesman for the RSPCA yesterday told the Telegraph that while dogs are omnivores and could theoretically survive on a w...

item.title: Why populists adore cats – and use them in their political propaganda - The Guardian
item.description:
Why populists adore cats – and use them in their political propaganda  The Guardian

Fans of Matteo Salvini, Italy’s rightwing, populist deputy prime minister, have been sending him images of their cats so he can post the cute, furry faces on his Facebook page and give his relentless attacks on migrants a more cuddly setting. Yet the idea that cat pictures are sweet is an internet-era development. In art, until recently, the cat was an evil creature. It is positively diabolical in Renaissance images of witchcraft. The German artist Hans Baldung Grien regularly included cats in his drawings of witches cavorting naked. While his witches offer themselves to Satan, their feline...

item.title: Things you only know when your pet goes missing while a cat killer is at large - The Telegraph
item.description:
Things you only know when your pet goes missing while a cat killer is at large  The Telegraph

The news that a cat killer may be on the loose in Brighton has highlighted the bittersweet nature of pet ownership. They can bring you so much joy – but when things go wrong, you suffer genuine pain. The thought that there may be someone stalking the streets of the East Sussex city, looking to deliberately harm a pet, is horrible – and it has brought back the heartache my family felt when our cat went missing while the hunt was on for the Croydon cat killer, the shadowy figure who police and animal activists believed was behind a spate of gruesome cat deaths around the south London area. We...

item.title: Keeping your pet safe during the season for bites, scratches and sunburn - ABC News
item.description:
Keeping your pet safe during the season for bites, scratches and sunburn  ABC News

Summer is the perfect time to be out and about with your pet, but it also means interactions with snakes, grass seeds, insects and the sun. Like humans, dogs feel the heat, and and can suffer from insect bites during the warmer months. Insect bites and skin irritations Veterinarian Melinda Salter said her practice at Southern Beaches in Tasmania received an influx of pet skin issues over summer. "Allergies tend to be a lot more prevalent over summer, with more flowers, dust and pollen around," she said. Photo: Summer brings more mosquitos, fleas and ticks, as well as grass seeds. (Reuters: ...

item.title: Cat got your abs? Fit feline caught doing sit-ups in undercover workout (VIDEO) - RT
item.description:
Cat got your abs? Fit feline caught doing sit-ups in undercover workout (VIDEO)  RT

Proving there is no excuse to miss ab day, a cat was captured fitting in an excruciating workout underneath a car in China. The fit feline used its surroundings for the impressive sit-up session caught on camera. The bizarre footage shows the cat secretly working on its little furry abs in a parking lot in Beijing last week. The short clip has been viewed more than 17,000 times since it was uploaded on Monday. #Cat performs sit ups underneath car pic.twitter.com/exmcOBjgd2 — CGTN (@CGTNOfficial) November 28, 2018 The fluffy white feline had an impressive technique for the workout, securing ...

item.title: Why dogs are no more intelligent than cats - The Independent
item.description:
Why dogs are no more intelligent than cats  The Independent

When your dog catches a tennis ball in its mouth on its first try or successfully rolls over on command, do you find yourself marvelling at its unparalleled intellect and talent? While your canine friend may have certain skills that are bound to impress an adoring crowd, a recent study has discovered that dogs may not be as smart as many people assume them to be. Published in the December issue of scientific journal Learning and Behaviour, psychologists from Exeter and Canterbury University undertook an investigation to determine how the cognitive abilities of dogs compare to those of other...

item.title: ‘This can't happen’: Salah speaks out against exporting Egyptian cats & dogs ‘as food’ - RT
item.description:
‘This can't happen’: Salah speaks out against exporting Egyptian cats & dogs ‘as food’  RT

Liverpool and Egypt forward Mohamed Salah has criticized an agriculture policy in his home country which plans on exporting 4,000 stray cats and dogs abroad, amid fears that the animals could be used for food. Salah has thrown his weight behind animal activists’ calls to end the practice, which is aimed at curbing a growing population of stray animals on Egypt’s streets. It follows a statement from the country’s Agricultural Ministry outlining plans to export 2,400 cats and 1,600 dogs overseas. Last month, politician Margaret Azir caused a media storm when she suggested ‘fattening up’ the s...

item.title: The Biggest Trends In The Pet Industry - Forbes
item.description:
The Biggest Trends In The Pet Industry  Forbes

The pet business is exploding Photocredit: The pet industry has been experiencing explosive growth. According to The American Pet Products Association, almost 85 million households have a pet and over the last 30 years pet ownership has gone from 56% to 68% of all households. Some of the changes in pet ownership are due to technology and the advent of online purchasing. But most of the growth is because of changes in culture. As millennial and Generation Z consumers have come into adulthood, they have embraced the pet-owning and pet-loving lifestyles to a far greater extent than their elder...

item.title: Tracking West Island's last feral cat - ABC News
item.description:
Tracking West Island's last feral cat  ABC News

By Matt Brann On the remote West Island in the Gulf of Carpentaria, Indigenous rangers say after years of hard work, there is now just one feral cat left on the island. An eradication program by the local Li-Anthawirriyarra Sea Rangers has used old and new technologies to eradicate the feral felines, with great success. While 1080 baits had been the main weapon since the project started in 2011, some cats wised up to the poisonous baits, which led rangers to try other methods to mop up the island's last few cats. Desert Wildlife Services ecologist Rachel Paltridge said the island had been p...

item.title: Meet Amsterdam’s official pet photographer - The Guardian
item.description:
Meet Amsterdam’s official pet photographer  The Guardian

In 2016, the photographer Isabella Rozendaal convinced Amsterdam’s city archives that a significant portion of the city’s inhabitants were being unfairly snubbed. Rozendaal was born in Amsterdam, and, when she is not travelling on assignment, she still lives there. Like other Amsterdammers, she considers the archives an invaluable resource – the public collection of historical documents (drawings, films, maps, photographs) is the largest in the world – but whenever she visited she always sensed something was missing. “Pets are a huge part of Amsterdam’s population,” Rozendaal says, “but the...

item.title: ‘They will be united in freedom’: Assange sends his cat away to safety - RT
item.description:
‘They will be united in freedom’: Assange sends his cat away to safety  RT

As the threat of extradition to the US hangs over Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder has been forced to keep his beloved pet cat safe by sending it away to live in exile with Assange family members. Residing in Ecuador’s London embassy since 2012, Assange’s safety became precarious last year when Ecuador elected President Lenin Moreno, a more pro-US voice than that of predecessor Rafael Correa and a man who described Assange as a “stone in our shoe.” Assange has since had his internet at Ecuador’s UK embassy cut, his visitation rights severely curtailed, and Moreno’s government has revok...

item.title: Why does my dog stare at the wall? When odd pet behaviours point to a serious condition - ABC News
item.description:
Why does my dog stare at the wall? When odd pet behaviours point to a serious condition  ABC News

Cats don't like to show signs of weakness, so if they're hurt, they often hide it very well. A vet told me this as he stretched my cat's back leg, adding that he could feel a bit of arthritis in it. The diagnosis wasn't unsurprising — my kitty is pushing 13 years old — but he advised keeping a close eye on her. In cats, conditions such as arthritis can go undetected until it's so bad that it's almost untreatable, the vet added. That got me thinking: pets can't explicitly tell us that they feel sore or sick. And the signs aren't always obvious. So what should pet owners be looking for? Sudde...

item.title: The scoop on how your cat's sandpapery tongue deep cleans - The Associated Press
item.description:
The scoop on how your cat's sandpapery tongue deep cleans  The Associated Press

WASHINGTON (AP) — Cat lovers know when kitties groom, their tongues are pretty scratchy. Using high-tech scans and some other tricks, scientists are learning how those sandpapery tongues help cats get clean and stay cool. The secret: Tiny hooks that spring up on the tongue — with scoops built in to carry saliva deep into all that fur. A team of mechanical engineers reported the findings Monday, and say they're more than a curiosity. They could lead to inventions for pets and people. "Their tongue could help us apply fluids, or clean carpets, or apply medicine" to hairy skin, said Georgia Te...

item.title: The National Cat Centre: giving hope (and homes) to unwanted cats - The Telegraph
item.description:
The National Cat Centre: giving hope (and homes) to unwanted cats  The Telegraph

There are three long-established charities that seem to comprehensively encompass animal welfare in the UK: the RSPCA, caring for all species of animals, Dogs Trust (formerly the Canine Defence League) caring for dogs only, and Cats Protection (formerly Cats Protection League), focused on just cats. Each of these charities has its origins in the 19th or early 20th century, and each has had to continually refresh and update its policies and strategies to stay relevant in a fast changing world. I discovered this for myself when I visited the Cats Protection headquarters recently. The charity ...

item.title: California wildfire: Vets battle to reunite pets with their owners after deadly blaze - The Independent
item.description:
California wildfire: Vets battle to reunite pets with their owners after deadly blaze  The Independent

Baylee Danz did not panic when she woke to the news of a wildfire nearby. Fires came with the territory in this place she had lived all her life, at the intersection between mountainous national forest and populated northern California towns. Until now, her family had been safe in Magalia, California, just north of Paradise. Only a few hours later, she was fleeing from the deadliest blaze in state history with her mother, father and grandmother. Her neighbour’s house was already burning down. The Camp Fire was at their heels and Ms Danz said she sobbed from loss and regret. Not only was she...

item.title: Who Let The Dogs In? IKEA Did, And Melted Some Hearts - Forbes
item.description:
Who Let The Dogs In? IKEA Did, And Melted Some Hearts  Forbes

With the stresses of everyday life, let’s face it, we could all use a feel-good story. IKEA in Italy. (Courtesy of Getty Images) And here is a great one, post-Thanksgiving, courtesy of an IKEA store in Catania, Italy. It turns out the IKEA store there has recently opened its doors to stray dogs in the area, not just cut-outs of shelter dogs, as it did in a previous campaign with Home for Hope to encourage pet adoption. The reaction has been phenomenal, with reports of some dogs even being adopted, according to the dodo. What a great idea, adopting a pet as you also buy a comfy couch. Quite...

item.title: New Louis Vuitton cat-inspired collection launched for animal lovers - The Independent
item.description:
New Louis Vuitton cat-inspired collection launched for animal lovers  The Independent

Louis Vuitton has created a new line of cat lady-inspired shoes, purses and clothes - and the pieces all features adorable kittens. The Catogram collection is a capsule collection designed by Louis Vuitton’s Nicolas Ghesquière and former Vogue creative director and avid cat illustrator Grace Coddington, who drew inspiration from their own pets. The pieces feature hand drawn sketches of Coddington’s Persian cats, Pumpkin and Blanket - and they will turn any person into an animal lover. - Read more Snapchat introduces new filters for cats In addition to leather handbags and purses, the collab...

item.title: Emotional Video Shows Woman Reunite With Cat Who Ran Off Into California Wildfire - HuffPost
item.description:
Emotional Video Shows Woman Reunite With Cat Who Ran Off Into California Wildfire  HuffPost

A heartwarming video shows the moment that a woman first lays eyes on the beloved cat she feared she had lost forever in Northern California’s devastating Camp fire. Laci Ping and husband Curtis Mullins took their gray tabby, Mayson, with them when they evacuated. But Mayson escaped from his cat carrier and sprinted away after an explosion startled him, according to a news release from the University of California, Davis. Luck was on Mayson’s side. Firefighters rescued him and, along with 22 other cats, delivered him to the UC Davis Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital on Monday. Ping saw h...

item.title: Sussex police launch investigation after cat stabbings in Brighton - The Guardian
item.description:
Sussex police launch investigation after cat stabbings in Brighton  The Guardian

Three cats are believed to have died after at least two were stabbed and another five were attacked in Brighton during the last two months. Sussex police have launched an investigation into the incidents, which were all reported within a short distance of Ditchling Rise in central Brighton since mid-September. Related: 'Croydon cat killer' hunt ends after three-year investigation A police spokesman said: “Sussex police have received further reports of injured or deceased cats following the suspected stabbing of a pet in Ditchling Rise, Brighton, on Monday [19 November]. Two officers have no...

item.title: The humble cat's tongue, like you've never seen it before - ABC News
item.description:
The humble cat's tongue, like you've never seen it before  ABC News

By science reporter Belinda Smith Look closely and you'll see a cat's tongue is exquisitely efficient at distributing saliva in its fur. Look closely and you'll see a cat's tongue is exquisitely efficient at distributing saliva in its fur. Tiger tongues are not easy to come by. So when 15-year-old Sumatran tiger Kavi died at an Atlanta zoo in 2016, Alexis Noel and David Hu made sure they had dibs on his tongue. It joined specimens from five other cat species — lion, tiger, cougar, bobcat and domestic cat — in a study of microscopic tongue structure. And it turns out your pet moggie's tongue...

item.title: Animal Shelters Cook Up Thanksgiving Dinners For Homeless Dogs And Cats - HuffPost
item.description:
Animal Shelters Cook Up Thanksgiving Dinners For Homeless Dogs And Cats  HuffPost

For dogs and cats in most animals shelters, Thanksgiving is just another day spent waiting for a home they can be thankful for. At some shelters, though, the holiday is marked with a special meal: turkey and all the trimmings, prepared in a way that won’t harm their health. The Providence Animal Center in Media, Pennsylvania, served dogs bowls of food with human-grade ingredients. “We are closed for the holiday, and we know that some of these babies are not going to find homes before the holiday, so this is a special way of showing them our love and appreciation for them before they find th...

item.title: Cat Finds Forever Friend In Firefighter Who Saved Her From California Wildfires - HuffPost
item.description:
Cat Finds Forever Friend In Firefighter Who Saved Her From California Wildfires  HuffPost

A firefighter tackling a deadly California wildfire made an unexpected friend in the form of an adorable, fluffy cat. The cuddly feline perched on Capt. Ryan Coleman’s shoulder as he surveyed the devastation caused in Paradise by the Camp fire, which has killed dozens of people and left thousands homeless. “Kitty rescue,” wrote Coleman, an engine captain at Fairview Valley Fire Department. “She just chilled on my neck and shoulders as I’d walk around.” Watch the video here: Coleman’s footage on Facebook has garnered more than 1.7 million views. It’s unclear what became of the cat. Coleman ...

item.title: 'An absolute little fighter': Eight lives left for kitten that escaped crusher - ABC News
item.description:
'An absolute little fighter': Eight lives left for kitten that escaped crusher  ABC News

By Tamara Glumac A tiny kitten has clawed its way out of a garbage crusher and up a tip worker's leg to safety after it and its siblings were thrown into a bin in Tasmania. And the brutal way in which the cat was discarded has not surprised animal welfare advocates. A tip worker had begun to operate the crusher at the Mornington Park Waste Transfer Station, north-east of Hobart, on Thursday when the male kitten, believed to be about four weeks old, made it out just in time. "He was in the crusher and the operator was there about to do some crushing and as the crusher was operating this litt...

item.title: Lewis Carroll's cat-astrophe, and other literary kittens - The Guardian
item.description:
Lewis Carroll's cat-astrophe, and other literary kittens  The Guardian

It is an apparently sweet illustration of Alice holding her black kitten Kitty before going though the mirror but it absolutely infuriated the writer Lewis Carroll. “Much over-printed … very bad,” is his testy, underlined scribble. Carroll’s Trump-like anger at the printing of his book Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice Found There is revealed in a new exhibition opening at the British Library which explores and celebrates cats in literature. On display for the first time is a rare book recently acquired by the library: Carroll’s own copy of the third edition, one of only three known ...

item.title: Cats, dogs, ducks and chickens saved from burning pet shop - ABC News
item.description:
Cats, dogs, ducks and chickens saved from burning pet shop  ABC News

By Lily Nothling Firefighters have come to the rescue of puppies, kittens, ducks and chickens after a fire broke out at a pet shop north of Brisbane early on Sunday morning. Six fire crews were called to the blaze at the large pet store at Kallangur around 3:00am, and arrived to see flames coming through the roof at the rear of the building. Inspector Leigh Campbell from Queensland Fire and Emergency Services said the animals were evacuated from the burning building while firefighters worked to bring the fire under control. "Crews got into action and realised very quickly there were animals...

item.title: Science news in brief: A test for Scottish wildcats to a discovery of a tiny ape - The Independent
item.description:
Science news in brief: A test for Scottish wildcats to a discovery of a tiny ape  The Independent

Test to tell endangered Scottish wildcats from domestic cats A genetic test has been developed to distinguish wildcats from domestic cats to help protect endangered species. The biggest threat to the Scottish wildcat, Felis silvestris, is widespread interbreeding with feral domestic cats. Between 45 to 100 purebred wildcats remain, mostly roaming remote parts of Scotland’s western Highlands. The Royal Zoological Society of Scotland is using the test to build a picture of the species’ status in the wild. However, the elusive and fierce animals are seldom available for testing. - Read more Sc...

item.title: Frankie Muniz Says His Cat Turned On Faucet And Flooded His Home - HuffPost
item.description:
Frankie Muniz Says His Cat Turned On Faucet And Flooded His Home  HuffPost

Hopefully, he’s insured. Former “Malcolm in the Middle” star Frankie Muniz says his five-story brownstone sustained major flood damage ― and his cat is the culprit. In a Twitter vent last week, the 32-year-old actor said he returned home from his uncle’s funeral in France to catastrophic destruction in his home ― several floors under water. “All because my cat accidentally turned on a sink a few days ago while we were gone,” he wrote. Muniz, who currently hosts “Dancing With the Stars: Juniors,” added: “I know this sounds ridiculous, but I swear it’s true.” Muniz said he cried more over two...

item.title: Residents fear erratic raccoons may have rabies, police say they are just drunk - The Independent
item.description:
Residents fear erratic raccoons may have rabies, police say they are just drunk  The Independent

Rabid animals are, of course, no laughing matter. The rabies virus can infect the central nervous system, resulting in disease and death, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But that happens after a host of increasingly serious symptoms: partial paralysis, agitation, hallucinations, hydrophobia. A British man and two children died in Morocco after they were bitten by a rabid cat. So it was not surprising that when people in the city of Milton, West Virginia, saw raccoons behaving weirdly, they involved the local police. Officers staked out the area where the suspect...

item.title: Rescuers field 5,000 calls in bid to save farm animals, pets from California's deadly fires - ABC News
item.description:
Rescuers field 5,000 calls in bid to save farm animals, pets from California's deadly fires  ABC News

A drove of donkeys, a herd of horses and even a large tortoise are among the farm animals and pets rescued by a host of volunteers in California as the most devastating wildfire in the US state's history ravages the landscape. Key points: - Actor Patrick Dempsey's farm animals were among those in need of rescue - Sandra Bullock donated $US100,000 to an animal welfare organisation in the wake of the fires - Not all animals managed to escape the wildfires More than 42 people were killed when the blaze incinerated northern Californian town, Paradise — some found in burned-out cars or the ruins...

item.title: Petco, others respond to demand for natural pet foods - The Associated Press
item.description:
Petco, others respond to demand for natural pet foods  The Associated Press

Demand for healthy, natural food is extending from humans to their pets. Petco announced Tuesday it will stop selling dog and cat food and treats with artificial colors, flavors and preservatives, both online and at its nearly 1,500 stores in the U.S. and Puerto Rico. "We are making sure we are always taking the nutritional high ground," Petco CEO Ron Coughlin told The Associated Press. Petco's move, the first of its kind among major pet stores, comes at a time when sales of natural pet foods are steadily rising. Natural pet products still account for a small portion of the U.S. market shar...

item.title: California communities rally to save animals caught in wildfires - CNN
item.description:
California communities rally to save animals caught in wildfires  CNN

When Jeff Hill returned to his neighborhood in Paradise, California, after evacuating during the Camp fire, he came across a wayward horse -- in a backyard swimming pool. The horse appeared to have jumped in to escape the flames, and was caught in the pool cover. He had been checking on a neighbor's house to see if it was still standing when he discovered the horse, Hill wrote in a Facebook post. "We scrambled to unhook the pool cover and pulled her to the shallow end where we guided her up the steps." The horse got out, shook off, and "loved on us for a few minutes as a thank you, and walk...

item.title: Reality Check: Your Dog Is Terrible For The Environment - HuffPost
item.description:
Reality Check: Your Dog Is Terrible For The Environment  HuffPost

Lyla is a pug, a very popular type of dog. She’s also a vegan. Her owner has stopped feeding her meat, a decision becoming more common among pet owners in the U.S. as people’s rising interest in meatless diets spreads to their pets. Lyla belongs to Myron Lyskanycz, CEO of the pet food company Halo. The business has sold both meat and vegan ranges of pet food for six years, and its meat-free products now account for 20 percent of dog food sales. Lyskanycz predicts vegan sales will grow quickly over the next decade. Around 8 percent of Americans describe themselves as vegetarian or vegan, acc...

item.title: Want to be a successful CEO? Get a dog - Fast Company
item.description:
Want to be a successful CEO? Get a dog  Fast Company

Behind most C-suite executives is a very good boy who definitely deserves a biscuit, according to a new survey of 857 working folks conducted by Kelton Research for Banfield Pet Hospitals. Turns out the path to career success doesn’t just run through Wharton, but starts with a childhood filled with puppies, kittens, bunnies, and hamsters. According to the survey, an astounding 93% of the C-suite executives surveyed grew up with a pet, and 78% partially attribute their career success in part to owning a pet as a child. Having a rescue dog to boop on the nose, a cat to try and turn into a mem...

item.title: Briton dies from rabies after being bitten by cat on holiday in Morocco - The Independent
item.description:
Briton dies from rabies after being bitten by cat on holiday in Morocco  The Independent

A British citizen has died from rabies after being bitten by a cat while visiting Morocco. Public Health England (PHE) issued a warning to travellers on Monday following the UK resident’s death. It said there was “no risk to the wider public in relation to this case” but health workers and close family and friends were being assessed and offered vaccination “as a precautionary measure”. Read more - Stop eating dog meat due to rabies risk, Hanoi tells citizens - Woman treated for rabies after bringing injured raccoon into her home No more details have been released about the case. Rabies doe...

item.title: Curious cats bring fame to Japanese museum that won't let them in - The Guardian
item.description:
Curious cats bring fame to Japanese museum that won't let them in  The Guardian

Two cats that have spent the past two years trying to enter an art museum in western Japan – only to be politely turned away at the door – have become online celebrities with a global following willing them on in their attempts to see at least one exhibit up close. Ken-chan, a black cat, attempted his first solo foray into the Onomichi city museum of art in summer 2016 during an exhibition of cat photography, but was prevented from entering by a security guard in a gentle standoff that was caught on camera. “I’m guessing that Ken-chan spotted some of the exhibits through the glass, and sinc...
